reviewText:
Cash shop aside, this game is pretty boring. The general idea is to build a scene where your cloth puppets beat the crap out of the other side's cloth puppets. You start by building resource generators for things such as wood and cloth. These resources are then used to purchase units to kick down the gate of the enemy. If you manage to reduce the enemy's gate to zero HP before they do the same to you, you win. Sadly, it is just not interesting.

PROS
1. Easy to Learn
Tutorial is simple to understand. Build a deck of cloth puppets and send them out to battle.

2. Graphics
The Unity Engine makes it look passable.

CONS
1. Cash Shop
$29.99 for 2070 buttons. Use it to buy more XP and Button Boosters. No thank you. I don't enjoy Pay To Win.

2. Low Population
100 seconds of waiting and no game.

3. Boring
Cloth puppets just don't excite me. I don't enjoy it.

Understand that the review of this game is based on a patch released on 17th September 2015, meaning that some of the problems I have with the balance of this game might  be changed if you are seeing this review on a later patch :)

Starting off, I don't consider this game pay to win like a lot of people are saying. The people saying this probably got matched into a couple of bad games and thought that the cards that other people had were unlocked through in game transactions. I got all of necessary cards by simply playing the game.

Gameplay & balance In terms of gameplay, the game is extremely unbalanced and can be hard for new players who don't understand how the level scaling works. When starting off, only having 3 cards and not having a solid strategy, the game can seem boring and unfair (not saying it isn't, but maybe not as much as the first impression might suggest). It generally consists of throwing out your robot and reaper in the lvl 1-2 range, beating your opponent in 30 seconds if they put their resources into production and didn't plan to counter your attack. Until lvl 7ish the game will consist of these cheesy strats, from my experience it seems you get random cards from matchmaking and so you might have a bad experience between these lvls, but by the time you get to around lvl 7ish you should have enough of the cards to make a solid deck. The problem I have at this point is that the Sabotage" card is way too strong and completely controls the game. Whoever uses this card effectively

reviewText:
Well, lets summarize the pros and cons after 2 and a half hours of playing:

Lets start with the negatives:
- there is a basic tutorial, but it is REALLY basic. It doesn't explain all the different things you can build and it doesn't tell you you should try things out in training mode.
- matchmaking is a little wonky, probably due to low amounts of online players. It can match you with people from the top of the rankings even in your first match.
- it takes time to get enough ingame currency to buy anything at all. Highest amount I got from a battle was around 250 whereas you need about 1k for a simple card upgrade from level 1 to 2 or 10k for 3 new random cards.

Up to the pros:
- The game is free to play and got the payment system implemented in a nice way. you can buy gold (rather low price compared to other F2P games) to get cards quicker or to buy avatars. Except for those Avatars everything else you need can be aquired by the ingame currency (the silver coins).
- The game really is a real time strategy game. It is fun once you understand it and there are multiple strategies that work out fine - well, if your opponent doesn't counter them that is ^^
- While grinding silver coins for upgrades and unlocks, you randomly get cards for battles. This makes it quite attractive to battle - also, battles are the best way to learn the game except:
- the chat - there are quite some players who'll help you if you have questions or need advice - well, there are also those who just scream how they can't get a grip on the game or how they get steamrolled. If that happens to you, just ask how you could improve and most players will answer - noobbashing is no fun anyhow ;)
- the graphics are easy on the eye .
- Ediths comment: As you can see in the comments here, the devs are quite active and take players seriously. THAT is a definite plus.

I'd recommend it for everyone. As a single battle doesn't take long you can't go wrong trying it - and don't get frustrated by the tutorial" - and don't worry about the cards you start with - atm my strategy is pumping out hedgehogs (one of the starters) while upgrading the smithy to give my creatures one more damage for each other creature I got. Hedgehogs give +2 damage to every other hedgehog in battle =3"

reviewText:
Since the developer bothered to respond to my comment, I gave this game another chance and it deserves a proper review now! Read below the quote!

QUOTE:

Icy Donut  [developer] Posted: 31 Aug @ 3:01pm
We apologize for the inconvenience.
We fixed most bugs, matchmaking and corrected chance of receiving new cards after battle. I hope you like the game now.

QUOTE END!

As stated, the major bugs seem to be fixed. It now is possible to have matches with other people without encountering heavy bugs.
There are still a lot of minor bugs to be worked on, but for a first impression of the gameplay, it is fine as for right now.

Matchmaking seems also quite smooth now. Sometimes the game would not really respond similar to a disconnect but it's just a major desync when trying to find a match.
But that's still one of the small bugs on here.

Cards are really obtained after most matches. Here I've won 8 matches in a row and got 4 new cards out of it.
Sometimes you may get the same card twice but you can simply sell it and get a few of those silver coins. I believe the purpose for them as for now is to buy another card slot to take one more card with you in battle and upgrading a current card.

About the chat I am very disappointed.
Majority is talking in russian. If it's not for those russians then there are other people spamming the chat with their own language.
Since this game seems to have players from everywhere, everybody should use english instead.
And some really do tho!

It is free to play so you won't lose anything on it. The in-game Shop is for paid currency only.
So you got to pay for faster leveling and more money gain.
That's a standard free to play model. And it seems that you can also get few of these real money currency after leveling up. For example I got around 30 when I turned level 6.

Upgrading cards can be done with either paid or legit currency as well as buying the new card slots.

There seems to be no item which let's you win easier or such.



Statement:

IF the developers continue to work a bit more on the game, refine the edges and smoothen the gameplay even more to fix even the small bugs, THEN I would recommend this game, since it is free to play and really not pay to win as well as it's kind of fun to play a few matches.

I reccomend this game because it's rather cute and fluffy, but it also takes some actual thinking to defeat your opponent. In response to the people saying this is a pay to win game, i disagree. If you get more than one type of a card you can't get rid of it or sell it which leads to multiple cards stacking up in your inventory. Some cards can be a little overpowered but you can easily get said cards and the devs are working on balancing the game.  There are some minor bugs and lag but nothing that has caused me to rage or lose a game.

Overall:
For a free to play game it is delightfull, although still in development.

reviewText:
Heroes of Scene feels like it’s more or less abandoned (and I say that as I’m trying the game out on the day that ‘big’ patch 1.2 has been released). There’s only 2-3 people playing (the game is multiplayer only), game content is extremely basic and the Steam forums are dead.

The game is almost like a proof of concept, vertical slice, early access build. The graphics are charming, and the foundation is reasonably solid, but other than that it’s hard to justify spending more than 30 minutes here. At least it’s free?

I’ll admit that I’ve played for a bit more than 30 minutes. This is largely because I picked up ‘Koshey’ in the one starter pack I was able to purchase with my ounce of free newbie gold. Koshey is known to be over powered and, what can I say, I do like winning so that’s kept me going. I have only lost one game rushing straight to level 10 and 2000 shields. (Shields are what passes for the game’s ranking system with a 2000 shield max (highest) rank.)

The game itself is extremely simple. Build some basic resource producing buildings (‘rooms’ in a house), ramp up production to build units, then send these units one by one towards the centre of the 2D, single-plane map.  The front unit from each player then proceeds to beat the snot out of the front unit of the other player until one player is ground back to their base and defeat.

Of note, the game desperately wants you to spend money, but seriously, on what? I can’t say, personally, because despite my winning streak I still haven’t earned enough in-game coinage to splurge on a single extra pack.

There are occasional card drops after winning a game but these are pretty stingy too – perhaps one card drop per five games or so, most of which were duplicates of cards I already had. This shouldn’t be surprising since the card pool seems tiny. Well, I guess, how much diversity can there be in lining up creatures @rse to toe in a conga line?

In a sense, there’s nothing wrong with giving this game a whirl for a few minutes. It’s free to play, after all. But there isn’t enough content, strategic diversity, other players or any significant sense of progression that might justify making an in-game purchase or medium-term time investment here.

reviewText:
This is my personal review of the game. I try to keep it as unbiased as possible, and that's rather easy considering I'm not a game developer fanboy. Keep in mind that this game is in Early Access at the time of the posting of this review and that things are most certainly subject to change. So, let's start out with the big bad wolf. The chief complaint people seem to have in this game. Pay to Win.

So, without further ado, let's go BallsDeep in this game.

The Business Model: Is it Pay to Win?

Everybody in the review section seems to be up and arms about how this game is Pay to Win. I decided, soley based on that theory, to download the game and play with it for a little while. Lo' and behold I came across my own pesonal decision on whether or not Heroes of Scene is P2W afterall. But I won't just give you what I think on the matter. I'm going to inform you properly with why I think what I do. So let's take a look at the business model, shall we?

Is there a cash shop? Yes, there is. Is this the devil? No, it's not. This is what you can buy in the cash shop. A premium membership with premium currency (buttons) for whatever time you select. This gives you double experience and money accumulation. You can buy some light cosmetics. This is just for your portrait. There's no way to get that with the earned currency, either. You can buy a random hero card or random spell card with premium currency. You can buy a new deck slot with premium currency, but also earned currency. You can also level up your hero and spell cards with both currencies however those cards still need to have the required experience before you can do so. You can also buy a new card slot (to fit more cards into your decks) for premium and earned currency, but must reach a certain level before you can even see the prices of that.

So, now that we know all (unless I missed something) of what you can buy in this game with real money / premium currency we can begin to answer the question Is Heroes of Scene Pay to Win?".

My answer is no
